conclusion: Analyze the motion of oil droplets under gravity, electric field, and air resistance to find proportionality constant k.
Initial velocity v0 of droplets A and B is h1/t.
Electric field E between plates is U/d.
Force due to electric field on charged droplet is Fe = qE.
Force due to gravity is Fg = mg.
Force due to air resistance is Fa = k m^(1/3) v.
Net force on droplet B is zero when moving upwards at constant velocity.
Electric force on B balances gravitational and air resistance forces: q U/d = m0 g + k m0^(1/3) h2/t.
Net force on droplet A is zero when moving downwards at constant velocity.
Electric force on A balances gravitational and air resistance forces: qA U/d = m0 g + k m0^(1/3) h1/t.
Subtract equations for B and A to find k: (qB - qA) U/d = k m0^(1/3) (h2 - h1)/t.
New droplet has mass 2m0 and velocity vnew.
Velocity of new droplet is average of velocities of A and B: vnew = (h1 + h2)/(2t).
Air resistance on new droplet is Fa,new = k 2^(1/3) m0^(1/3) (h1 + h2)/(2t).
Electric force on new droplet balances gravitational and air resistance forces: qnew U/d = 2m0 g + k 2^(1/3) m0^(1/3) (h1 + h2)/(2t).
Charge on new droplet is qnew = qA + qB.
Solve for k using previous equations.
Proportionality constant k is m0^(1/3) g d t (h2 - h1)/(U (h1 + h2)).
